main_content:
Help

Update Feature Images on Home Page
To update the feature images with captions at the top of the home page, you’ll need to log in. After logging in, click on the feature image (note that the feature images do not fade into each other when you are logged in. This is to help make editing them easier). The in-place editor should appear. Click on the right-most button, called the "code" button (it is blue and looks like this: <>). You should see code similar to this (with code for all of your feature images and captions):
<div id="featureImages"> 
  <ul>  
    <li>
      <img src="uploads/picture2.jpg" alt="alternate text goes here">  
      <div id="caption">  
        <h2>Caption for featured images</h2>  
        <p>Words for caption</p>  
      </div>  
    </li>  
    <li>  
      <img src="uploads/picture1.jpg" alt="alternate text goes here">  
      <div id="caption">  
        <h2>Caption for second featured image</h2>  
        <p>Words for caption</p>  
      </div>  
    </li>  
  </ul> 
</div>
To Edit a Feature Image or Caption:
  • To change a caption, just edit the words you want changed. When you are finished editing, click the code button again at the top left, and then click "Save" at the bottom of the page.
  • To change an image, change the name of the image within the img tag. For instance, in the code above, if we had just uploaded a new feature image (see below for details on how to do this), and it was called picture3.jpg, if we wanted to replace the first feature image, we would replace the "picture2.jpg" with "picture3.jpg".
  • We then need to add a description of what is in the image in the "alt" (which stands for "Alternative Text", and is for blind readers who can’t actually see the picture, as well as for search engines). Change the text of the alt (the text between alt=" and ") In the above code, we might change alt="alternate text goes here" to alt="A lovely sunset" if the image where a picture of a sunset.
  • When you are done, click the code button again (the blue <> at the top), and then click Save.
  • Now logout, and view the home page to see if everything worked according to plan (you should see the updated feature image and captions).
To Add a New Feature Image With a Caption:
  • To add a new image and captions, just copy the code for a current feature image from the list (the code for a single feature image should look something like this):
     <li>  
      <img src="uploads/picture1.jpg" alt="alternate text goes here
    ">  
      <div id="caption">  
        <h2>Caption for second featured image</h2>  
        <p>Words for caption</p>  
      </div>  
    </li>
  • Now paste that code where you want the new feature to appear in the list. If you want it to be the first in the list of feature images to appear, paste it right after <ul> and before the first list item (<li>). If you want it to be the last, paste it right after the last list item (</li>) and before the end of the unordered list (</ul>).
  • Now that you have code where you want it, just change the image URL, alt text (see above), and the caption and caption description.
  • When you are done, click the code button again (the blue <> at the top), and then click Save.
  • Now logout, and view the home page to see if everything worked according to plan (you should see the new feature image and captions).
Edit a Page
To edit a page, just login and click on the content of the page that you want to edit (even if the page doesn’t exist yet). Make sure to have an H1 title at the top of the page, and use p for paragraphs. If you know html, you can look at and change any of the code on the page by clicking on the "Code" button (it is blue, it is the right-most button, and it looks like this: < >). You can add any html here that you want.
When you are pasting in content from another program, like Microsoft Word, you will need to copy and paste the text into a simple text editor like Notepad first (to get rid of crazy proprietary formatting code that gets added), and then copy and paste that text into the text editor on the web page. Do not ever paste text that is copied directly from an email, a PDF, or a Word document! (You will end up with a very strange looking Web page.)
See below for adding an image to the page. To delete an image already on the page, just double-click the image. To move the image, just click and drag it to the desired location (note that this will move the image up and down, not horizontally on the page…to move the image horizontally from right to left or vice versa, open the code view, find the image you want to change and change "float:left;" to "float:right" or vice versa, or "float:none;" if you don’t want text to flow around it).
Click Save when you are happy with the new page. Click Cancel if you have accidentally messed something up, and want to start over again with the old page.
Create a New Page
To create a new page:
  1. Figure out what you want the URL to be. For instance, if the new page is a Faculty page with all faculty listed, a good URL would be "faculty". If the new page is a page for Hillary Clinton, a good URL would be hillary_clinton (no capital letters, replace spaces with underscores, and no weird characters like apostrophes or plus symbols, etc.). Once you have the URL figured out, go to that page using the Address bar on you browser (where you type URLs). So for the faculty page, you would type http://nmbcc.indiana.edu/faculty. When you go that page, you’ll notice that it says that the page that doesn’t exist. No matter, you’re making a new one.
  2. Click on the text of the page, and edit the title and text. Add images if you want (using the image upload button, see below for details about adding images).
  3. Click Save when finished creating the page. Now your new page exists, and other people can see it, but only if you email them the URL (there is no link to the page on the site yet, so even Google can’t see it).
  4. You can now have other people review and edit the page until you have it just the way you want it.
  5. Remember to add a page title to the page using the Edit Page Title button on the top of the page (in the Admin menu).
  6. When you are happy with the page, and are ready for it to be made live, you’ll need to add a link to the page on another page of the site or in the top navigation menu.
Delete a Page
To delete a page, go to the page you want to delete, and click on "Delete Page" at the top in the Admin menu. Click the box that says "Yes, delete it!", and then click "Delete". The page is now no more (actually it’s in Purgatory).
Undelete a Page
Have you accidentally deleted a page and want it back? Worry no longer, there is a way out of this. First, you’ll need an FTP program (like WinSCP) on your computer (or Dreamweaver will work too). Connect to the Web server, and open the www folder on the server. Inside that, there is a folder labelled "archive". That’s where all the bad little pages go when they die until they’ve paid off their debts to society. Within that folder, find your deleted page. For instance, if you accidentally deleted the people page, find people.json. Now copy and paste that file (in this case, people.json) into the folder labelled "pages". Voila, page undeleted, back from the dead...hopefully not a zombie.
Add an Image to a Page
Adding an image to the site is fun and easy... or at least easy.
  1. You’ll need to resize and rename the image before you put it on the site. Resize the image you want to add using Photoshop on your computer. You should resize the image to be small in size (300px wide or so, except for the feature images on the home page, which should be exactly 884px wide and 340px high) and choose the option in Photoshop "Save for Web & Device", and save the image as a jpg on your computer using a simple filename with few letters and/or numbers and no spaces or special characters or parentheses.
  2. Click on text on the Web page where you want to add the image.
  3. Now click on the Upload Image button on the text editor on the Web page (it looks like a Polaroid picture of a tree), and drag the image from your desktop to the upload box. When the upload is finished, the server will now have a copy of that picture, and will have created a small thumbnail for the front page.
  4. You will find the newly uploaded picture in the list of Uploaded images below the upload box. You can search for the filename using the search box, or scroll to find the image. When you have found the image you want to add, click on the blue "Insert" button. Add a description of the image (for blind users and for Google Images to find), choose an alignment, and set the width of the image in pixels (make this the number of pixels of your image, e.g. if you resized your image to be 200px wide, put 200 in the box). Now click the "Insert into Page" button, and the upload popup box will close, and you should see the new image inserted into your page. Click and drag the image to move it around on the page, and double click it to delete it from the page.
  5. Click Save.
Add Video to a Page
For video, it will be best to upload your video to YouTube, and embed from there (this keeps the huge file size of the video on YouTube’s servers, not IU’s). To put the YouTube video on your page, go to edit the NMBCC page that you want to put the video on, and click on the code view (a blue <> in the editor on top). Find the place that you want to add the video in the code, and then in another browser window or tab open the YouTube page. Below the video on YouTube, click the "Share" button and then click "Embed" and copy the long embed code. The YouTube embed code should look something like this:
<iframe width="560" height="315" src="http://www.youtube.com/embed/0JA0s-4Ng2Q" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen></iframe>
Paste this into the code on the NMBCC page, click the code button (it is blue and looks like this <>) again to go back to the regular editor and click "Save". This should embed your video. If you want a larger or smaller video size, just change the width and height in the embed code to the desired height and width.
Update or Create a Page Title
Page titles are the words that appear in the Web browser’s tab to the right of the tiny IU icon. This allows users to see what page they are on within your site even when they are using a different browser tab. It also helps Google figure out what your content is about (a good thing). So create a short clear title for every page. You can do this by clicking on "Edit Page Title" in the very topmost Admin menu (the black bar at the top of every page that has grey buttons on it, one of which you clicked already to view these Help instructions;).
Click on the current title to edit (or on the words "Click to edit" if there is no current title). Change to the desired page title. For instance, if this is the People page, you would put People here. If this were the Squid Legs page, you would put Squid Legs here. After you are happy with the title, click Save. After clicking save, refresh the browser, and view your beautiful new page title text in the browser tab at the top of the browser. Note that by default all pages have "Neal-Marshall Black Culture Center at the end of every title (you don’t need to add this, it is added automatically when you edit the title). This is so that people and robots (like Google’s) don’t forget what site they are on.
Edit Top Navigation Menu
To edit the top navigation menu (the menu that has Home, About, At the House, etc. as well as drop down menus), you are going to need to edit some code. Oh no, code! Don’t worry, it’ll be nice and easy (we hope). One quick note, however: Don’t ever have more than 9-11 links in the top navigation bar, or more than 6-8 in the dropdown menu. More than this will tend to overwhelm the user (too many choices). Also, be very short and clear with your text. If a link is for All The People in the Department, make the text say "Department" or "People". One word is optimal (but only if users will be able to understand it without other words). More than three words is nearly always too many.
  1. Click on the grey "Edit Menu" button at the top of the page. The dropdown should say Top Navigation Menu, and there should be grey buttons with the menu items and submenus. Click on any of the light grey items in the list (this is Click to Edit like everything else).
  2. The code for the navigation menu should show up. Let’s say, for example, that you want to change the Visit Us link to say Find Us instead. Find the line of code that currently says Visit Us. It should look like this:
    <li><a href="visit">Visit Us</a></li>
    Change the Visit Us text to Find Us like so:
    <li><a href="visit">Find Us</a></li>
  3. Click "Save". Refresh the page, and notice how the menu is now different.
  4. To add a new link to the menu, copy and paste a line of code (like the line of code above) to exactly where you want the new link in the order of the menu. Then change the text and the URL of the link (the URL of a link is what is between the <a href=" and the end of the quote (">). For instance, if the url of the new page is http://nmbcc.indiana.edu/people, and the title of the page is People, then change the line of code to say:
    <li><a href="people">People</a></li>
  5. To delete a menu item (like to get rid of the People link in the top navigation), just delete the entire line of code in which the text appears, and click Save.
  6. If you would like to understand the html (code), check out the Help section "What Does All of This Code Mean?" for a quick rundown.
Fix a Previous Content Formatting/Coding Mistake
Do things look funky on a Web page? Are you (and others) wondering "What’s going on?" Sometimes the visual editor has problems and creates bad code (and sometimes we accidentally mess up a page’s code by moving things around and formatting things). Not a problem. You have access to change the code behind the page. In the editor, click on the code button (a blue <>). Now you can edit the code to your heart’s content (although I’ve never heard of someone’s heart becoming content from code). For a very quick rundown of html code, see the Help section "What Does All of This Code Mean?"
Most mistakes can be fixed quite easily just by knowing how html works. Nearly every beginning tag should have an ending tag (<h1> is the beginning tag of a level 1 heading, and </h1> is the ending tag, and the content of the heading is in the middle of these). <br> will give you a line break. Check out W3Schools.com for many quick tutorials on how to write and edit html.
What Does All of This Code Mean?
HTML means Hypertext Markup Language. It is a language like other language, and has a vocabulary, syntax, grammar, etc. HTML is used to make Web browsers understand what parts of a page are. The Web browser receives the html, and interprets it into something visual (so that your Website visitors can see the parts of the page, and not just read them). So a top heading is h1 (heading 1). If there are secondary headings, we use h2 (heading 2). There is h3, h4, h5, etc. for lower headings. By default these lower headings are smaller in font size in the browser to show users visually their hierarchy. Tags go around each piece of the page that they are describing. So if the heading "Facilities" is the top level heading for a page, we surround it with h1 like so:
<h1>Facilities</h1>
Nearly every html element (h1 is called an element) has a beginning tag (like <h1>) and an ending tag (like </h1>) with the content in the middle of them.
<p> stands for paragraph, <ul> for unordered list (has bullets), <ol> for ordered list (has numbers or letters usually), and <li> is for each list item. If we want to make something strong or bold, we can use <strong>. To emphasize (which makes the font italic), we use <em> the same way as we used <strong>.
To add a link, we need a couple of things:
  1. Start the link with <a>, which stands for anchor.
  2. We add a space at the beginning after the a and a reference to where the link should go (the full http URL): <a href="http://google.com">. If the link is to a page on the same site, we do not need to have the http or the domain name, just the page name: <a href="people">
  3. Now we will add the text that is clickable and then have the ending tag (in this case, we are linking to the People page): <a href="people">People</a>
  4. Anything that is between the beginning and ending tags is part of the link (including any images).
To add an image, just include it from the image uploader, and move it to where you want it to appear.
If you get confused about any code, check out W3Schools.com for a great resource to all things html. And if you get really stuck, just email the creator of NoMoreCMS, Bob Wadholm (rwadholm@indiana.edu) for advice or quick tips.
